New Records: Adolis García had 15 RBIs in the Rangers' series against the Houston Astros, a record for a player in a single ALCS series.
García also set a record for total bases in a Game 7 with 10, including two homers and two singles that produced five runs batted in.
Key Match Events: García's overreactions in Game 5 triggered a 25-minute delay, which allowed the Astros to score and ultimately win the game.
García hit a grand slam in Game 6 while under immense pressure in Houston.
The Rangers outscored the Astros 20-6 over two games in the ALCS, forcing a Game 7.
García had two run-scoring singles to left, a solo opposite field homer, and a solo big fly to left in Game 7, helping the Rangers win 11-4.
Pre-Game Insights: Chris Young, the Rangers' general manager, said that García loves the big moment and is an unbelievable person with a great work ethic.
García's manager, Bruce Bochy, emphasized the importance of getting on top of Cristian Javier's magic fastball in Game 7.
Post-Match Reflections: García said that he was focused solely on Game 7 and didn't want to say or do anything that would get him off track from performing in the game.
Chris Young said that García's performance in Game 7 was awesome and that he just worked his way into a great major leaguer.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Rangers' offense is a fast-break basketball team that scores in bunches quickly, made possible by their lineup depth.
García is hitting.327 in 12 postseason games with 20 RBIs and a 1.102 OPS, just one RBI short of the postseason record.
García has seven home runs this postseason, three short of the record of his former roommate, Randy Arozarena.
Others: The Rangers' turnaround performance is a testament to Bombi's Law, which holds that baseball teams can do an about-face in two years or less.
García's journey from being designated for assignment twice to becoming the ALCS MVP is a remarkable one.
